Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Megabit-Per-Second Underwater Wireless Communications
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project lies in addressing a long-standing roadblock to the further development of undersea technology. Today, there is no wireless broadband communication available underwater. Each remotely operated vehicle requires a tether for communication and a support ship for tether management. The proposed modem technology is video-capable and would obviate the need for tethering and expensive support ships. In 2013, the subsea industry demanded more than 123,000 ROV days and these are expected to increase to at least 140,000 days in 2017. An ROV support ship costs about $120k/day totaling over $7B spent on ROV support ships in 2013. The proposed video-capable modems would be sold to ROV manufacturers and operators that want to eliminate the need for ROV support ships and much of the $7B in associated cost. The proposed modem technology connects remotely operated vehicles and machinery to wired infrastructure, enabling safe operation of heavy subsea machinery without the possibility of cables or tethers getting tangled, causing damage or worse. This project will create 10 new jobs in the next three years, with many more to be added as the production is scaled-up.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project proposes to develop a faster, cheaper, more reliable wireless communication system for the sub-sea industry. Current state of the art communication links for the deep ocean are either tethered, requiring long, bulky, expensive cables to connect machinery and systems, or have extremely low data rates, enabling only the most rudimentary of tasks. The proposed underwater wireless communication system will provides data rates in the Mbps (megabits/sec) range - 1000 times faster than existing underwater wireless communication technologies - and enable video streaming and real-time control of subsea infrastructure, machinery, and mobile underwater vehicles. Since radio signals do not propagate far underwater, the proposed technology uses sound waves, as whales and dolphins do, for communication. The speed of sound is 200,000 times slower than the speed of radio propagation, and mobile acoustic transmitters and receivers hence suffer from severe Doppler distortion. The proposed technology dynamically measures, tracks, and compensates for this distortion, to enable wireless communication at data rates never before possible underwater.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main technical objectives of this Phase I project was the development of a proof-of-concept for an underwater wireless communication technology capable of operation at rates of 1Mbps and over distances of up to 100m. The main goals of this phase I were to identify suitable components for such a proof-of-concept, to deploy these in a range of tests, both in wave-tank as well as lake experiments, and to translate a laboratory equipment-based research setup to a real-time processing environment, capable of streaming video.  These technical objectives were all met prior to the award of the Phase IB supplement.  A real-time software framework was implemented running proprietary communication algorithms on an embedded system. Extensive field-tests (wave-tank and open-water) demonstrated that this proof-of-concept modem can operate at Mbps rates at distances up to 100m. This technology uses ultrasonic waves for sending information and is 1000 times faster than commercially available acoustic modems. Due to the relatively low speed of sound, acoustic communication underwater suffers from Doppler effects that are five orders of magnitude worse than for radio communication on land. These effects have been the primary obstacle to higher data rates underwater, but they have been addressed successfully in this project. Computer controlled motion experiments verified that platform speeds at and beyond what is typically seen in remotely operated vehicle (ROV) missions (3 knots) do not degrade the performance of our modem prototype.

The main technical objectives of the Phase IB supplement were focused on 1) developing and designing high-performance underwater sound absorber elements that enable emulation of the deep-sea horizontally-reflectionless operational environment in an indoor wave tank; 2) testing the variability and sensitivity of the modem to the number, placement and material properties of scattering surfaces in the wave tank facility; and 3) testing and characterizing the modem performance at all relevant levels of salinity and turbidity in the controlled wave tank environment. Extensive testing has been carried out, and all of the technical objectives have been met.

The Phase IB technical objectives were to test the modem at the environmental parameters of interest to customers in the subsea oil and gas industry. At subsea oil and gas production sites, visibility is poor due to particles stirred up by ocean currents and work-class ROVs and the space is cluttered with oil and gas production equipment such as wellheads, manifolds, pipelines and umbilicals. High turbidity/low visibility environments significantly hamper the performance of free-space optical communication systems, a competing approach to wireless underwater communication that modulates optical signals (LED or laser) to convey information. In this Phase IB project, it was demonstrated that the performance of the acoustic communication technology developed in this project is essentially unaffected when water clarity changes from pristine to Gulf of Mexico levels or when salinity increases to even beyond seawater levels. Carefully designed, and crafted high-performance sound absorber elements were characterized. When properly lined with such sound absorbing elements, the acoustic characteristics of the indoor water tank more closely resemble the deep sea environment being horizontally reflection-free. This allows certain experiments to take place at an indoor facility that otherwise would need to be conducted in a much larger body of water, thereby saving time and expense.
